Ireland is bound by the International Telecommunication Convention which lays down that all stations must be established and operated in such a manner as not to cause harmful interference to the radio services of other countries which are members of the International Telecommunication Union.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It is being contravened.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The radio regulations under the convention provided that no transmitting station may be established or operated by a private person or by any enterprise without a licence issued by the Administration of the country to which the station is subject. Against this background of international agreements, the operators of illegal broadcasting stations in particular have placed this country in an embarrassing position vis-à-vis the other members of the International Telecommunication Union. Within the State — I am not saying this happened particularly in Kiltimagh — there have been numerous complaints of interference caused to various authorised radio services by the many categories of illegal users of wireless telegraphy apparatus. Re-broadcasting stations have been offenders in this respect.
If no attempt is made to apply the law, the consequences will be chaotic for orderly frequency spectrum management and usage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It should be applied equally. It should be applied in Dublin West before 25th of this month.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: In this regard it is my intention shortly to introduce the Independent Local Radio Authority Bill which will provide an orderly framework for the development of local radio services here. It is also my intention to introduce concurrently with the Independent Local Radio Authority Bill the Broadcasting and Wireless Telegraphy Bill which will strengthen the powers of my Department to deal effectively with unlicensed broadcasting stations and other categories of unlicensed wireless telegraphy apparatus. This Bill was on the Order Paper of the Dáil at its dissolution in May 1981 but was not re-introduced during the term of the Coalition Government.

I regret any inconvenience caused to the people of Kiltimagh. I look forward to having a frank discussion with them when they send their delegation as soon as a meeting is arranged. There is one possibility I feel I must mention. There is a statutory order which exempts from the licensing requirement Cable TV systems with fewer than 100 subscribers. I understand there are fewer then 100 subscribers in the Kiltimagh area. It is worth considering. Kiltimagh was first brought to my attention at school in the poem which says: “Go Coillte Mághach rachad, go ndéanfad cuairt miosa ann, agus beidh fáilte romham, Tá cairde agam ann.”
The Dáil adjourned at 9 p.m. until 2.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 12 May 1982.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Area Farmers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Burke Mr. L. Burke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason farmers living in disadvantaged areas engaged in mixed farming of sheep and cattle are not receiving the full subsidies of £1,820 for sheep and cattle; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: An applicant in the Disadvantaged Areas in both the Cattle Headage and Sheep Headage Schemes in 1981 could be paid on a total of 30 livestock units (equivalent to 200 ewes) between both schemes.
An applicant with 200 ewes could be paid the maximum payable of £1,750 (not £1,820) — i.e. payment at a rate of £9.50 on 150 ewes and at a rate of £6.50 on the remaining 50 ewes.

MainHeading.P: An applicant with less than 200 ewes but with enough cattle to bring the total livestock units up to 30 could not be paid the maximum of £1,750 because the rate of payment on cattle was not as favourable as on sheep. For example, an applicant with 160 ewes (24 livestock units) and six livestock units on the cattle side could be paid £1,490 for sheep (150×£9.50+10×£6.50) and £192 on the cattle side (6×£32, the rate payable per cattle livestock unit), i.e. £1,682 in all.

In a small number of cases where an applicant who applied under both schemes was paid on the cattle livestock units first instead of being paid on the sheep at the more favourable rate, the Department will recalculate the grant and pay the balance due.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Erne Catchment Study Report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the action being taken to implement the Erne catchment study report; and when work on the ground will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins)
Speaker.P: The Government are committed to the implementation of the Erne catchment area study and the relevant Government Departments have been requested to act on the recommendation contained in the study as far as is possible within available resources.

The investigation into the feasibility of restoring the Ballinamore-Ballyconnell canal has already commenced. The improvement of the N3 (Cavan By-Pass) and the N16 routes is accorded priority in the Government's road development plan for the 1980's. Work is also proceeding to convert the manual telephone exchanges named in the study to automatic working by the end of 1983. Particular attention is being paid to the recommendations of the Erne Study with regard to measures to be implemented under the non quota section of the ERDF. Co-ordination will take place where necessary with the Northern Ireland authorities on the implementation of the study.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. G. Fitzgerald)
Speaker.P: Following the announcement by the Government in October 1980 of the centres designated for the location of civil service offices, representations were made that other centres, including South Tipperary, be included in the programme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Service Pension Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cluskey Mr. Cluskey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service if he will furnish the following particulars of public service pension schemes sanctioned by his Department and at present in operation other than those co-ordinated schemes and schemes under the Superannuation Acts, 1948 and 1956; (1) title of scheme, (2) date of last amendment, (3) employee contribution per £100 of pay for gratuity, (4) employee contribution per £100 of pay for pension, (5) employee contribution per £100 of pay for widows' pensions, (6) maximum lump sum or gratuity and (7) maximum pension as a percentage of retiring pay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. G. Fitzgerald) Minister for the Public Service (Mr. G. Fitzgerald)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. G. Fitzgerald)
Speaker.P: In so far as the Civil Service is concerned the information sought by the Deputy is as follows:—

(1) Title of scheme: The superannuation code as enshrined in the Superannuation Acts, 1834 to 1976. (2) Date of last amendment: Civil Service Superannuation Regulations, 1980, made under section 3 of the Superannuation and Pensions Act, 1976, giving effect to a number of amendments in the superannuation code. (3) and (4) Employee contribution per £100 of pay for gratuity and pension: The civil service scheme is non-contributory. (5) Employee contribution per £100 of pay for widows' pensions: The contribution rate under the Civil Service Spouses' and Children's Contributory Pension Scheme is 1½ per cent. (6) Maximum lump sum or gratuity: One and a half (1½) times final pensionable salary. (7) Maximum pension as a percentage of retiring pay: Half salary, except for female established civil servants serving on 12 April 1954 who did not adopt the provisions of the Superannuation Act, 1954, who are eligible for a pension of two-thirds (2/3rds) salary but no retiring lump sum.

MainHeading.P: In so far as information may be required in respect of schemes relating to other areas of the public service, it is suggested that the matter might be raised with the Ministers under whose aegis those areas are covered.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Port and Docks Board Superannuation Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cluskey Mr. Cluskey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Transport if he will furnish the following particulars of the principal features of the Dublin Port and Docks Board's superannuation scheme: (1) the maximum gratuity, (2) the maximum pension, (3) the contribution per £100 of wages for a gratuity, (4) the contribution per £100 of wages for an occupational pension, (5) the contribution per £100 of wages for a widow's pension and (6) whether the scheme is co-ordinated with social welfare pensions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: Dublin Port and Docks Board have two superannuation schemes, the officers' scheme and the employers' grade A scheme. I presume that the Deputy is referring to the employees' grade A scheme. The information sought is as follows:—
(1) Maximum gratuity: 45/30 of pensionable remuneration (based on 1/30 of pensionable remuneration for each year of pensionable service) i.e. a sum equivalent to one and one half years pay.

(2) Maximum pension: 40/80 of pensionable remuneration (based on 1/80 of pensionable remuneration for each year of pensionable service) i.e. an annual allowance equivalent to one half of final year's pay.
(3) Contribution per £100 of wages for gratuity and (4) Contribution per £100 of wages for occupation pension: 4?% (the percentage contribution is not broken down in respect of (3) or (4).
(5) Contribution per £100 of wages for widows' pension: 1½%

MainHeading.P: (6) Whether the scheme is co-ordinated with the Social Welfare pensions: The scheme is not co-ordinated with the Social Welfare pensions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is aware of difficulties at present being experienced by Irish nurses in connection with the recognition of courses which they have undergone in other EEC countries; the reason for such difficulties; the action he proposes to take in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Minister for Health (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: It is not clear what difficulties the Deputy has in mind. Only one level of nurse is recognised in this country, i.e. registered nurse. In most other EEC countries, there are two levels of nursing recognised. An Irish national cannot be given recognition in Ireland for a level of training lower than that equivalent to the training given here to registered nurses.

The EEC directives on general nursing provide for freedom of movement and lay down minimum standards of training for registered nurses. Assuming that other member states comply with the directives there should be no difficulty in an Irish national who qualifies in another member state being registered here on return. If the Deputy is aware of any particular problem, he might communicate with me and I will have the matter examined.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Raphael Burke)
Speaker.P: Proposals submitted by Dublin Corporation for the development for housing purposes of two sections of the designated area (sections C and D), comprising approximately 88 dwellings, have been approved. I understand that Dublin Corporation propose to invite tenders in the near future for the erection of a number of the dwellings in these sections and to commence work on them in the present year.

MainHeading.P: In regard to the designated area as a whole, my concern is to ensure the provisions, as soon as possible, of an overall balance in development in the various sections of the area by ensuring a suitable mix of housing, industry, open space, social, educational and community facilities and other amenities. I understand that in the light of these considerations, which have been impressed on corporation officials in the course of recent discussions, the corporation are radically reviewing their proposals for the balance of the designated area (sections A and B). When revised proposals for sections A and B are submitted to my Department by the corporation they will be examined as expeditiously as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if any research is being carried out into the apparently widespread grwoth of Ivy Hedra Helix, an ivy which is increasingly evident on trees throughout the country and which eventually can kill the trees involved; whether he is concerned about the present situation; and if he will take appropriate action to ensure that the situation is dealt with.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Daly)
Speaker.P: Between 1973 and 1980 the Forest and Wildlife Service of my Department carried out experiments designed to evaluate the effects of ivy on tree growth in State plantations. These tests produced no evidence to indicate that ivy is damaging to trees in any material way. No impairment of growth was evident due to ivy infestation and even moderately healthy trees appeared to be able to resist adverse effects from the growth of ivy.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ardee Garda Area Control.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Markey Mr. Markey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will consider the placement of the Ardee Garda area, County Meath, under the control of either Drogheda or Dundalk superintendents rather than under the superintendent at Navan as at present.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: The position is that, following a survey of the Louth/Meath Division by the Garda Research and Planning Unit which resulted in the re-establishment of Navan Garda District with effect from 15 July 1975, the sub-district of Ardee was transferred from the Drogheda district to the Navan district. I am informed by the Garda authorities that, following consultation with the local Garda officers, they are satisfied that this arrangement is operating satisfactorily and they do not consider that the reallocation of Ardee to either the Drogheda or the Dundalk district would result in an improved police service for the area. In the circumstances, no change in the present arrangement is contemplated.
